There is a lot of misdirection in that post. I wouldn't recommend using it as a blueprint or taking any of it as advice. 

PES is nowhere near T3. It has great placements and people regularly end up at Amazon and the like if they work hard on upskilling and being hireable. For a college that boasts a median and average of 12-14L and a highest of 50+L, if you don't end up with a good job then it's on you for not putting in the hard work when it matters, or for not being industry ready and being eligible for the roles they come hiring for. You can't blame the college for being mediocre when you were mediocre yourself.

And once you start working, there is no concept of "off campus". *Everything* is off campus, and which college you come from is completely irrelevant. All that matters is your work experience, how you performed at your previous role to advance in your career, and what you bring to the table. Nobody looks at your college once you've spent enough time in the industry; if you're good at what you do, you're a good candidate to interview. The entire story of "making it off campus from T3" is logically flawed here because it isn't even relevant to the discussion.

Luck will only take you a short way. Everything else depends on your hard work. Put in so much effort that your own skills can take you places luck cannot. And focus on your CGPA. It matters. Everywhere. All opportunities from jobs, placements, internships, higher education - all depend on your CGPA. Don't screw this up. 

Fair praise to the dude for making it to Amazon. But stories like these are one in a thousand. Kids, there are no shortcuts in life. If you want success, you're going to have to earn it.

>Just wanted to share an anecdote that itâ€™s possible to eventually become successful even in todayâ€™s job market, even if you didnâ€™t do anything in college

Know your audience. Stories like these are dangerous to students preparing to step into college. They do not know how the real world works, and often take anecdotes as pathways of life to live by. I'm happy for your success, but you shouldn't be parading your story around, especially with those choices of words. "I'm proof that it's still possible to break into FAANG despite ..., "It's never too late to find success" - these phrases simply sell your story to people who do not read between the lines. 

Your entire story paints you as someone who did not work hard throughout their life (college or their job), yet found the stepping stones to success by chance. Surely there is something *else* to also highlight here, right? What about the times you realised that having studied more would have helped, or the times you felt that having put in hard work would have prevented you from getting laid off? You are sharing your story of rags to riches, but you did not take any accountability for your circumstances.  Those lessons are just as important. Instead of telling people to work hard to not be in your shoes, you are claiming that being in your shoes is okay because it might work out in the end.

For every one of you, there are thousands in this country who end up struggling to find a job, and I am pretty sure you are aware of this. Being a senior who is multiple years older than the current batch of incoming students, *and* a fellow senior to me as well, you should know better than to put out posts that are 90% misdirection and 10% reality. Your story isn't quite what you think it is. 

Stop parading your story as a comfort read. It's, at best, false hope. You aren;t motivating anyone.
